title: 1953–54 Northern Rugby Football League season
text:
The 1953–54 <a href="Rugby%20Football%20League">Rugby Football League</a> season was the 59th season of <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> football played in <a href="England">England</a>. The <a href="Rugby%20Football%20League%20Championship">championship</a>, which involved thirty teams, started in August, 1953 and culminated in a finals play-off series in April, 1954 which resulted in a championship final between <a href="Warrington%20Wolves">Warrington</a> and <a href="Halifax%20R.L.F.C.">Halifax</a>. The season was also punctuated by the <a href="1954%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1954 Rugby League World Cup</a>, the first ever, and is also notable for its <a href="Challenge%20Cup">Challenge Cup</a> final, which was drawn and had to be re-played, attracting a world record crowd for a rugby football match of either code.
Season summary.
The 1953–54 season saw <a href="Brian%20Bevan">Brian Bevan</a> become the highest try scorer in rugby league history when he passed the 446 tries mark set by <a href="Alf%20Ellaby">Alf Ellaby</a>.
<a href="Warrington%20Wolves">Warrington</a> won the <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20leagues">Lancashire League</a>, and <a href="Halifax%20R.L.F.C.">Halifax</a> won the <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20leagues">Yorkshire League</a>. <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St. Helens</a> beat <a href="Wigan%20Warriors">Wigan</a> 16–8 to win the <a href="RFL%20Lancashire%20Cup">Lancashire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a>, and <a href="Bradford%20Bulls">Bradford Northern</a> beat <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull F.C.</a> 7–2 to win the <a href="RFL%20Yorkshire%20Cup">Yorkshire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a>.
Championship.
Play-offs.
Final.
The Championship Final was played between Warrington and Halifax on 8 May (three days after the epic Challenge Cup re-play) at <a href="Maine%20Road">Maine Road</a> before a crowd of 36,519. The match was televised by the <a href="BBC">BBC</a> and it was a tremendous defensive effort that helped Warrington to a narrow 8–7 win, with <a href="Harry%20Bath">Bath</a> kicking 4 goals.
Challenge Cup.
The <a href="1954%20Challenge%20Cup">1954 Challenge Cup</a> was the 53rd staging of rugby league's oldest knockout competition, the <a href="Challenge%20Cup">Challenge Cup</a>. It featured clubs from the 1953–54 Northern Rugby Football League season and is notable for its Final which had to be replayed before possibly the largest crowd in rugby league history.
